item.title: India Ink: Mumbai’s ‘Focus’ Festival Showcases Women Photographers
item.description: Work by Indian and international female photographers deals with free speech and emancipation.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: March 15
item.description: The papal election; Syria’s bitterly personal war; pig carcasses and the food supply in China; European leaders insist on austerity; and a new show from an all-male dance company.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Demonstrators protested government budget cuts in Brussels on Thursday while officials met.

item.title: India Ink: Flora and Fauna of India
item.description: Paintings commissioned by Europeans in India in the 18th century at the Arader Galleries in Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: When Is Activism Worth Getting Arrested?
item.description: While no one knows how many environmental activists around the world have run afoul of the law during their protests, the numbers are growing.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE
item.media:description: Police arrest environmental activists opposed to the Keystone XL tar sands pipeline project outside the White House in February.

item.title: India Ink: Leadership Change in Nepal Stirs Hopes of Stability
item.description: The country moves towards holding new elections under an interim government.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Ieng Sary, Khmer Rouge Leader Tied to Genocide, Dies at 87
item.description: Mr. Ieng Sary was part of an inner circle of communists who led the movement that caused the deaths of 1.7 million people in Cambodia from 1975 to 1979.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SETH MYDANS
item.media:description: Ieng Sary in 1996 with former members of his radical Maoist movement who were allowed to join the Cambodian Army.

item.title: Lens Blog: A New Oral History of Documenting the Iraq War, 'Photojournalists at War'
item.description: A new book, “Photojournalists at War,” is an oral history of the Iraq war from the perspective of three dozen photojournalists who documented it from the front lines.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DEXTER FILKINS

item.title: The Battle Over Syria
item.description: Despite strategic gains, anti-government fighters continue to struggle.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Iran Nuclear Weapon to Take Year or More, Obama Says
item.description: President Obama made the comments to an Israeli television station less than a week before his first visit as president to that country.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Tensions Mount in West Bank
item.description: An Israeli mother and three children were seriously injured in a car crash in the West Bank on Thursday after stones thrown by Palestinians apparently hit their vehicle, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Coca-Cola Asked About GPS Use
item.description: Coca-Cola has said it is cooperating with Chinese authorities who are investigating whether its employees engaged in illegal mapping using GPS devices in Yunnan Province.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Bahrain: Dozens Hurt During Protests
item.description: Dozens of people were injured as protesters clashed with the riot police on Thursday on the second anniversary of a Saudi-led military intervention in Bahrain.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: North Korea’s Sexist Barb Stirs Gender Issue in South
item.description: South Korea’s first female president, Park Geun-hye, daughter of a dictator and admirer of Margaret Thatcher, is considered tough on security, but North Korea is testing her.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: South Korea’s president, Park Geun-hye, at a recent military ceremony, has sought to take a tough line with North Korea.

item.title: U.S. Says a Greek Helped Iran Evade Sanctions
item.description: A business executive and 14 of his companies are accused of conspiring with Iran to sell that country’s oil in defiance of international restrictions.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: India Bars Italian Envoy’s Exit
item.description: India demanded that the Italian ambassador explain why his country is refusing to return two Italian marines to stand trial for the killing of two Indian fishermen, an official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Iran Pursues U.S. Drone Over Persian Gulf
item.description: The encounter, the second since November, illustrated the dangers that such pursuits could lead to hostilities between the United States and Iran.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: Argentines Divide Over Selection of Pope Francis
item.description: Some residents of Buenos Aires described an archbishop who had worked hard to change the lives of the poor, but others said he had done too little to challenge the country’s former dictatorship.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Muslim Brotherhood’s Words on Women Stir Liberal Fears
item.description: In a statement on a proposed United Nations declaration to condemn violence against women, the Brotherhood issued a list of objections, which formally laid out its views on women.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL-SHEIKH
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman on a bus watched a protest against sexual harassment in Cairo last month. Advocates of women’s rights worry that things will get worse for women.

item.title: Pope Francis, Fan of Saints, on Soccer Field and Off
item.description: San Lorenzo de Almagro, an Argentine soccer team with holy beginnings, now has a supporter at the Vatican in Pope Francis I.
item.dc:creator: By JESSICA WEISS
item.media:description: The future pope with a jersey of the San Lorenzo de Almagro soccer team in Buenos Aires in May 2011.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Filling the Pews: Challenges for the New Pope
item.description: Roman Catholics around the world share their views on the leadership of the church, and Daniel J. Wakin reports from Rome.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Argentine Church Under the Shadow of the Dirty War
item.description: The election of an Argentine cardinal as Pope Francis has rekindled a controversy about the role of the Roman Catholic Church during the blackest period of his country’s modern history.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Argentines celebrated the election of Pope Francis at the Metropolitan Cathedral in Buenos Aires on Wednesday.

item.title: Pope Francis Shifts Vatican’s Tone With Simple Acts
item.description: Whereas Benedict XVI was a theologian who favored ermine-lined cloaks and erudite homilies, Francis appears to be sending a message of radical humility.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: Pope Francis on Thursday with Cardinal Santos Abril of Spain, left, and Cardinal Agostino Vallini, the Vicar General of Rome.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Best Metros in the World — Hong Kong, Bangalore, Tashkent…
item.description: When Rendezvous asked readers about their favorite metro, we received hundreds of impassioned responses. Public transport, and especially its failings, can spark quite a debate.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE BARTHELEMY and MARCUS MABRY
item.media:credit: Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The #7 subway train rattles above Queens Boulevard in New York City.

item.title: New Pope’s Piety and Humility Aided His Surprise Selection
item.description: Francis’ march to the papacy began with the meetings of cardinals that occurred before the conclave. His remarks struck a chord, but he held on to a low profile.
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL J. WAKIN
item.media:description: Pope Francis led Mass at the Sistine Chapel on Thursday.

item.title: In Battle for Highway in North, Syria’s Civil War Writ Small
item.description: A battle for a stretch of northern road that government forces still risk using pits a conventional arsenal against fighters armed with faith as much as weapons.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of an Islamic brigade, the Falcons of Syria, in Heesh in the north, where antigovernment forces have won territory.
